ratingSummary.consensus: The Nice Guys hearkens back to the buddy comedies of a bygone era while adding something extra courtesy of a knowing script and the irresistible chemistry of its leads.

title: The Nice Guys
advisory: for violence, sexuality, nudity, language and brief drug use
synopsis: Shane Black (Iron Man 3) directs this police drama set in Los Angeles during the 1970s, and centering on a pair of detectives who stumble into a sprawling conspiracy while investigating the alleged suicide of a once-prominent female porn star. Russell Crowe and Ryan Gosling top-line this Warner Bros. release that reunites Lethal Weapon scribe Black with that film's producer, Joel Silver. ~ Jason Buchanan, Rovi

reviews.quote: Ryan Gosling's best performance this year, and Russell Crowe's best work in a long time.

The Nice Guys loses its way time and again, and generally not in an intriguing manner. The filmmakers rely on too many clichés and shortcuts (psychotic hitmen, quirky thugs and such) and too much pointless, time-wasting violence.
Funny and even thrilling by times, but its greatest trick is to make you fall on side with these two not-always-so-nice-guys.
The humor rarely flows naturally, instead arriving in the form of squabbling asides, designed specifically to be separate, segregated moments outside of the plot.
This mostly disappointing effort from Shane Black can be described much like the private dicks of the title-not exactly great, or even good, but ensures you'll at least have a nice time watching it.

A fantastic throwback to several eras. At its heart it's a classic 1940s film noir...wrapped in the polyester styling of 1970s crime films...contains the fun 1980s buddy-film banter and chemistry...punctuated by the ultra-violence of the 1990s.
With outrageous situations and sharp dialogue, Shane Black is someone who has perfected the buddy cop formula and in The Nice Guys it's an absolute blast.
Through the writing and direction, Black has taken something familiar and gave it its own identity. We get the best of his cinematic obsessions, ranking in the top tier of his oeuvre.
This is the kind mismatched buddy action comedy that, every time one does roll around, we collectively say, "Hollywood doesn't make this kind of movie anymore."
The excessive police buffoonery flows very well, but without much coherence. [Full review in Spanish]
No shocker, Shane Black is amazing.
